dublin_core: Thomas, Jakita O. Minor, Rachelle Odemwingie, O. Carlette 2017-06-19T11:36:14Z 2017-06-19T11:36:14Z 2016-07 Thomas, J. O., Minor, R., & Odemwingie, O. C. (2016). Exploring African-American Middle-School Girls' Perceptions of Themselves as Game Designers In Looi, C. K., Polman, J. L., Cress, U., and Reimann, P. (Eds.). Transforming Learning, Empowering Learners: The International Conference of the Learning Sciences (ICLS) 2016, Volume 2. Singapore: International Society of the Learning Sciences, pp. 35-43. https://doi.dx.org/10.22318/icls2016.146 Computational algorithmic thinking (CAT) is the ability to design, implement, and assess the implementation of algorithms to solve a range of problems. Supporting Computational Algorithmic Thinking (SCAT) is a longitudinal project that explores the development of CAT capabilities by guiding African-American middle school girls through the iterative game design cycle, resulting in a set of complex games around broad themes. This paper explores African-American middle school girlsâ€™ (called SCAT Scholars) perspectives of their SCAT experience and perceptions of themselves as game designers. en Singapore: International Society of the Learning Sciences Exploring African-American Middle-School Girls' Perceptions of Themselves as Game Designers Book chapter <dc:subject xml:lang="en">computational algorithmic thinking</dc:subject> <dc:subject xml:lang="en">SCAT</dc:subject> <dc:subject xml:lang="en">game design</dc:subject> <dc:subject xml:lang="en">girls</dc:subject>
